Also accessible from State Hwy 71, 25 miles on unpaved River Road.
data.weatherInfo: Summers can be very warm, high 90's to 100 with the possibility of thunderstorms late afternoons.  Winter temperatures can dip as low as -20 with some snow and wind.  Heaviest snows can be expected in late Spring.
data.name: Agate Fossil Beds

operatingHours.description:
The park's two trails are open from dawn till dusk every day.

Visitor Center features Miocene Mammal fossils, a 12 minute movie, and the James H. Cook Collection,  a unique collection of American Indian artifacts that were gifts to James Cook and his family.
operatingHours.name: Trails

data.description:
During the 1890s, scientists rediscovered what the Lakota Sioux already knew—bones preserved in one of the world's most significant Miocene Epoch mammal sites.

Yet, this place called "Agate" is a landscape that reflects many influences—from early animals roaming the valleys and hills, to tribal nations calling the High Plains home, to explorers passing through or settling in the American West.

images.altText: The visitor center sits in the middle of mixed grass prairie.
images.title: Visitor Center on the Prairie
images.caption: From the Fossil Hills Trail the Visitor Center is a ship in a sea of prairie grasses.

images.altText: Tipis and Fossil Hills represent the two subjects that Agate Fossil Beds interprets.
images.title: The Agate Fossil Hills and Tipis
images.caption: One of the first impressions that visitors have are the tipis and the Fossil Hills.

images.altText: Thunderheads are common in July.
images.title: A July Storm Passes
images.caption: Summer storms include thunderheads and lightning and can be exciting and dangerous.

images.altText: The Dinohyus was a scavenger, nicknamed "Terrible Pig"
images.title: Dinohyus in the Visitor Center Fossil Diorama
images.caption: Visitors stare in wonder at the huge head of the "apex" predator of the plains some 20 million years ago.

images.altText: This buckskin shirt decorated with quills was worn by Red Cloud.
images.title: The James H. Cook collection
images.caption: Visitors agree that this shirt decorated with quillwork and worn by Red Cloud of the Oglala Lakota is a priceless piece of history.

data.directionsInfo: The park is located on Amaknak Island in the Aleutian Island chain. The island is located 800 miles west of Anchorage.  The island can be reached by commercial or charter air flights from Anchorage. Commercial flights to Unalaska include Pen Air and Alaska Airlines. The Alaska Marine Highway is a ferry service that is operated by the state that can be used to reach the island.  The Aleutian World War II Visitor Center is located at the Unalaska airport.
data.weatherInfo: The Aleutian Islands are known for unpredictable and stormy weather. Rain, fog, and wind are common. Dress warmly and carry rain gear even in summer. Summer temperatures range from 45 to 65 degrees F. Early summer and fall often have clear sunny days with spectacular views of the surrounding volcanoes.
data.name: Aleutian Islands World War II
data.description: During World War II the remote Aleutian Islands, home to the Unangax̂ (Aleut) people for over 8,000 years, became a fiercely contested battleground in the Pacific. This thousand-mile-long archipelago saw invasion by Japanese forces, the occupation of two islands; a mass relocation of Unangax̂ civilians; a 15-month air war; and one of the deadliest battles in the Pacific Theater.

images.altText: Group of people around a Russian cross in tall grass
images.title: A homeland changed
images.caption: In September 2009, Nick Lekanoff, Sr., former Makushin resident, traveled with his daughter and other descendants of Makushin on the Tiglax to visit the village site, which had been left behind in the evacuation of 1942 and never permanently resettled.

images.altText: Twelve men and a dog pose for a photo
images.title: William C. House and the Aerological Detail on Kiska
images.caption: After his aerological crew was captured by the Japanese in June, 1942, Senior Petty Officer William House survived 50 days in the hills of Kiska.  He ate grass, shellfish, and worms. Weighing 80lbs he surrendered and was respected for his perseverance.

images.altText: People crowd at the railing of a ship
images.title: Evacuation and internment
images.caption: Pribilof villagers, here lining the railing of the USAT Delarof on the day of their departure (June 15, 1942), were evacuated with only a few hours notice and no idea of their ultimate destination.

images.altText: Four men gather around a invalid man
images.title: Challenging weather conditions
images.caption: Soldiers rub the frostbitten feet of a disabled soldier. Over 2000 weather-related casualties—the majority Attu feet—were recorded for U.S. troops. This number represents the largest classification of casualties suffered by American forces on the island.

images.altText: Six men with guns carry a person on a stretcher in a valley.
images.title: The battle for Attu Island
images.caption: U.S. wounded are gathered from the battlefield on Attu Island.  The battle on Attu, lasting nearly 20 days, was the second most deadly in the Pacific Theater.

images.altText: A uniformed man holds up a broken Russian cross
images.title: Cultural collision
images.caption: The Aleutian campaign brought together Russian, Native Alaskan, Japanese, and Euroamerican cultures. During the war 7 historic churches were damaged or destroyed. Villages were unrecognizable or burned to the ground and personal belonging lost or stolen.

data.fullName: Aleutian Islands World War II National Historic Area

The park is centrally located along the western shoreline of Saipan, adjacent to downtown Garapan.
From airport, proceed north on Airport Road (Tun Herman Pan Highway) until the road ends at Monsignor Guerrero Road (Highway 16). Turn left and continue until the road ends at Beach Road. Turn right until the road ends at the American Memorial Park Mall. Turn left onto Micro Beach Road. The parking lot is on the right.

The temperatures are stable throughout the year.

data.description: American Memorial Park honors the American and Marianas people who gave their lives during the Marianas Campaign of World War II. At the park, memorials stand in tribute to the courage and sacrifice of the US Servicemen and Chamorro and Carolinian civilians who were killed in the battles between the United States and Japan that took place on Saipan, Tinian, and the Philippine Sea in 1944.

images.caption: The beach is an inviting place to swim and relax.

data.description: On April 9, 1865, the surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia in the McLean House in the village of Appomattox Court House, Virginia signaled the end of the nation's largest war. Two important questions about its future were answered. Could the nation survive a civil war intact, and would that nation exist without slavery? The answer to both was yes and a new nation was born.

The Bering Land Bridge Visitor Center is located in Nome, AK. Nome, AK is not on the road system and may be reached via a commercial flight. The Bering Land Bridge Visitor Center is located about a mile from Nome Airport. 

Bering Land Bridge National Preserve is located in the northern portion of the Seward Peninsula. There are no roads or trails into the parklands. Logistics on how to reach Bering Land Bridge is based on an individual’s resources and abilities.
data.weatherInfo: Weather in the Seward Peninsula is generally characterized by long freezing winters and short, cool summers. Coastal areas typically have mild weather, while the interior has greater seasonal variation in temperature and precipitation.
data.name: Bering Land Bridge

operatingHours.description: Bering Land Bridge Preserve is open 24/7 year round. Due to its remote location accessing the preserve can be challenging, costly and time consuming.

data.description: Bering Land Bridge National Preserve lies at the continental crossroads that greatly influenced the distribution of life in the Western Hemisphere during the Pleistocene Epoch. It is a vital landscape for indigenous communities who depend on the land just as their ancestors did for many generations. It is a wild and ecologically healthy landscape unlike any other.

data.directionsInfo:
Bighorn Canyon has two districts that are separated by a three hour drive.  

To get to the North District at Fort Smith, MT from Billings,take Interstate 90 south to Hardin, MT. Turn at exit 495 onto State Highway 313 to St. Xavier and then to Fort Smith, Montana.

To get to the South District at Lovell, WY from Billings, MT, take Interstate 90 west. Turn at exit 434 at Laurel, MT. Turn onto US 310 East/US 212 South. Turn at US 310 East to Lovell. The visitor center is on the east side of Lovell.
data.weatherInfo:
North District: Semi-arid, receiving 18 to 20 inches of rain annually.
South District: High-desert, receiving 6 to 10 inches of rain annually.
Summer temperatures: Highs in the 80s (F) and 90s (F), lows in the 50s (F) and 60s (F). Summer temperatures can peak over 100 degrees.
Winter temperatures: Range in the 20s and 30s with low temperatures averaging the 10s (F) and 20s (F). During the winter the thermometer can drop below 0 (F) with extreme wind chill factors.
data.name: Bighorn Canyon

operatingHours.description: The park is open every day. The Yellowtail Dam visitor center in Fort Smith, MT is only open from Memorial Day to Labor Day. The Cal S. Taggart visitor center in Lovell, WY is open 8:30 - 4:30 daily.

operatingHours.description: Following guidance from the White House, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and state and local public health authorities, Big Hole National Battlefield is increasing recreational access. The NPS is working  with federal, state, and local public health authorities to closely monitor the COVID-19 pandemic and using a phased approach to increase access on a park-by-park basis. Beginning June 20, 2020, the visitor center will be open Friday - Sunday, 9am-5pm, while the rest of the park is open daily.
operatingHours.name: Big Hole National Battlefield Visitor Center

data.description: On August 9, 1877 gun shots shattered a chilly dawn on a sleeping camp of Nez Perce. By the time the smoke cleared on August 10, almost 90 Nez Perce were dead along with 31 soldiers and volunteers. Big Hole National Battlefield was created to honor all who were there.

images.altText: Multiple tepee poles and a river are silhouetted against a dawn sky.
images.title: Battlefield at Dawn
images.caption: Today tepee poles stand sentinel at the site of August 9th, 1877 dawn attack at the Big Hole.

images.altText: Blue camas flowers dot a green field with tepee poles in the background.
images.title: Camas Blooms Near the Nez Perce Camp at the Big Hole
images.caption: The Nez Perce chose their camp site in the Big Hole in part due to the Camas, whose roots they gathered prior to the August 9th attack.

images.altText: a cannon overlooks a valley and distant mountains
images.title: Mountain Howitzer at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.caption: Nez Perce warriors captured and dismantled the Mountain Howitzer cannon before the US army could use it effectively at the Battle of the Big Hole.

images.altText: cross country skis rest against a large granite monument on a snowy day.
images.title: Monument to the US Soldiers and Volunteers at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.caption: In 1883 the United States Government erected this monument in honor of the soldiers and volunteers that served and died at the 1877 Battle of the Big Hole.

images.altText: Stone carving of a Nez Perce Warrior's head in full regalia.
images.title: Chief Joseph Memorial at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.caption: This monument, erected on the Big Hole Battlefield in 1928, reads; "To the everlasting memory of the brave warriors Chief Joseph's Band who fought on these grounds in the Nez Perce War of 1877."

images.altText: Three large stone monuments and four interpretive signs overlook a series of low hills.
images.title: Bear Paw Battlefield

data.weatherInfo: The weather along the Cumberland Plateau can be best described as unpredictable. Each season brings its own weather patterns. Summers are generally hot and humid, with high temperatures sometimes eclipsing 90 degrees. The low temperatures in winter often dip below freezing. Spring sees the most amount of precipitation, but rainfall can occur in various amounts throughout the year.

data.description: Encompassing 125,000 acres of the Cumberland Plateau, Big South Fork National River and Recreation Area protects the free-flowing Big South Fork of the Cumberland River and its tributaries. The area boasts miles of scenic gorges and sandstone bluffs, is rich with natural and historic features and has been developed to provide visitors with a wide range of outdoor recreational activities.

data.description: Life of all types abounds in the Big Thicket. This national preserve protects the incredible diversity of life found where multiple habitats converge in southeast Texas. Hiking trails and waterways meander through nine different ecosystems, from longleaf pine forests to cypress-lined bayous. It is a place of discovery, a place to wander and explore, a place to marvel at the richness of nature.

images.altText: Knobby cypress knees resembling cave stalagmites protrude up from a pool of water.
images.title: Cypress Knees
images.caption: Knobby knees, extensions of the root system, are a distinctive feature of the bald cypress trees.

images.altText: A dense stand of funnel-shaped carnivorous pitcher plants awaiting their next insect meal.
images.title: Pitcher Plants
images.caption: Look for carnivorous pitcher plants in bogs along the Sundew Trail and Pitcher Plant Trail.

images.altText: Three people paddling kayaks along a waterway densely lined with bald cypress trees.
images.title: Kayakers in Cooks Lake
images.caption: Kayaking is a popular way to explore the many waterways in the Big Thicket. Here, kayakers paddle along the Cooks Lake Paddling Trail near Beaumont.

images.altText: The yellow flowers of pitcher plants bloom beneath longleaf pine trees.
images.title: Pitcher Plants and Pines
images.caption: Early April is the best time to see wildflowers blooming in the Big Thicket..

images.altText: A woman and her dog on a metal bridge spanning a creek lined with bald cypress trees.
images.title: Hiker on bridge over Village Creek
images.caption: The view from the bridge over Village Creek is a highlight for hikers on the Kirby Nature Trail.

data.description: The Blackstone River runs from Worcester, MA to Providence, RI. Its waters powered the Slater Mill in Pawtucket, RI, America's first successful cotton spinning mill. This creative spark began the nation's transformation from Farm to Factory. Today, the Blackstone River Valley is a special type of National Park - a living landscape containing thousands of natural and historic treasures.

data.description: The Blackstone River powered America's entry into the Age of Industry. The success of Samuel Slater's cotton spinning mill in Pawtucket, RI touched off a chain reaction that changed how people worked and where they lived, and continues to reverberate across the nation to this day. Come visit and see how this revolution transformed the landscape of the Blackstone Valley and then the United States.

data.directionsInfo: Brices Cross Roads National Battlefield Site can be found 15 miles north of Tupelo, Mississippi. Exit U.S. Highway 45 onto Mississippi 370, in Baldwyn, Mississippi. The battlefield is located 6 miles west of Baldwyn, on Mississippi 370. Visitors may also consider visiting the Mississippi's Final Stands Interpretive Center in Baldwyn. Exit U.S. Highway 45 at Mississippi 370 and turn east. Take the first right off of Highway 370 to the interpretive center.
data.weatherInfo: Mississippi is classified as a humid subtropical climate, the weather ranges from mild winters to hot summers with high humidity between May and September. Average high temperatures reach into the high 80's in summer, and into the high 40's in winter. Check local forecasts to plan your trip.
data.name: Brices Cross Roads

operatingHours.description: The grounds of the Brices Cross Roads National Battlefield Site are open sunrise to sunset everyday of the year.
operatingHours.name: Brices Crossroads National Battlefield Site

data.description: The Confederate victory at Brices Cross Roads was a significant victory for Major General Nathan Bedford Forrest, but its long term effect on the war proved costly for the Confederates. Brices Cross Roads is an excellent example of winning the battle, but losing the war.

images.altText: The monument with cannons on each side
images.title: Brices Crossroads Monument

operatingHours.description: From March through September, Buck Island is open to visitors between 6:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. to 5:30 p.m, October through February. Anchoring is restricted to the West Beach anchoring area. An annual permit is required for all vessels, including those vessels entering the lagoon to access the underwater trail moorings or to scuba dive. Overnight use of the West Beach Anchoring Area requires a special overnight permit from Christiansted National Historic Site.
operatingHours.name: Buck Island Reef National Monument

data.description:
Welcome to Buck Island! Before you come, please watch our 2014 Telly Award winning film "Caribbean Gem." Watching this will catch you up on 50+ years of National Park Service protection and civic engagement. Learn what we do every day to preserve this resource for Virgin Islanders and visitors alike.

For the General Management Plan and Environmental Compliance, visit the News page.

images.altText: Snorkelers in formation departing the concessioner's vessel in route to the underwater trail.

images.title: Tropical dry forest, Buck Island
images.caption: The plants that make up the subtropical dry forest on Buck Island range from old historic tamarinds to gumbo limbo, from cactus to delicate orchids.

images.altText: Photograph of rainbow at Buck Island

images.caption: Buck Island is a magical place! Come snorkel the waters and hike the trails.

images.altText: green sea turtle hatchling on beach heading towards the ocean

data.directionsInfo:
The recommended route to the park is from Highway 191 in Chinle then turning east on Route 7. The park entrance and Visitor Center is about 3 miles from Highway 191.

An alternative is entering the park on the East side via Route 64. There are 3 overlooks to stop at along Route 64 before getting to the Visitor Center.

Travel on Route 7 from the East is NOT RECOMMENDED since the road is unpaved and unmaintained between Sawmill and the Spider Rock turnoff.
data.weatherInfo: Canyon de Chelly is located at 5,500 feet.  Spring is cool and windy; highs from 50 to 70; lows of 35 degrees.  Expect dust storms and canyon flooding. Summer is hot and dry; highs from 85 to 100; lows of 51 degrees.  Drink plenty of water outdoors. Fall is warm and often wet; highs from 60 to 80; lows of 40 degrees.  Expect lightning, thunderstorms, and flash floods. Winter is cold and breezy; highs from 40 to 60; lows of 18 degrees. Expect 1-4 inches of snow and freezing nighttime temperatures.
data.name: Canyon de Chelly

operatingHours.description: North Rim Drive, South Rim Drive, 10 overlooks and White House Trail remain open all year round.

data.description: For nearly 5,000 years, people have lived in these canyons - longer than anyone has lived uninterrupted anywhere on the Colorado Plateau.  In the place called Tsegi, their homes and images tell us their stories. Today, Navajo families make their homes, raise livestock, and farm the lands in the canyons. A place like no other, the park and Navajo Nation work together to manage the land's resources.

images.altText: Farm in the canyon
images.title: Canyon Farm

images.altText: Hiking in the canyon

images.altText: View of Spider Rock from the overlook

images.caption: Her home on top of Spider Rock, Spider Woman taught the Navajo people how to weave

images.altText: View of the canyon from the White House Trail

images.caption: The Navajo people call the canyon Tsegi meaning "within the rocks"

images.altText: View of White House Ruin
images.title: White House
images.caption: Ancient Puebloans built villages like White House that offered opportunities for trade, ceremony, and social gatherings.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee required to visit Cape Krusenstern National Monument
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance

data.directionsInfo: Cape Krusenstern National Monument lies within a remote area of northwest Alaska and is bordered by the Arctic Ocean and Chukchi Sea.  Visitors generally access the monument via the regional hub in Kotzebue. Commercial airlines provide daily service from Anchorage to Kotzebue. Chartered flights with licensed air taxi services, booked in advance, can take backcountry travelers to remote destinations within the monument.
data.weatherInfo: Snow, rain, and freezing temperatures can occur any time of the year. Always travel with good quality rain gear and warm layers. Be especially careful to stay dry. Hypothermia can set in on a windy, wet day, even when it doesn't feel that cold.
data.name: Cape Krusenstern

operatingHours.description: The Northwest Arctic Heritage Center is the visitor center for Cape Krusenstern National Monument.  Since there are no roads into Cape Krusenstern National Monument, the visitor center is located in Kotzebue, AK.  From Kotzebue, visitors will charter an air taxi to transport them into the actual national monument which is open 24/7 every day of the year.
operatingHours.name: Cape Krusenstern National Monument

data.description: North of the Arctic Circle, the monument forms 70 miles of shoreline on the Chukchi Sea.  More than 114 beach ridges provide evidence of human use for 5,000 years.  The Inupiat continue to use the area today.  Vast wetlands provide habitat for shorebirds from as far away as South America.  Hikers and boaters can see carpets of wildflowers among shrubs containing wisps of qiviut from muskoxen.

images.altText: muskox standing on the tundra
images.title: Muskox and Geese
images.caption: Muskox and Greater White-fronted Geese on vegetated beach ridges in front of the Igichuk Hills.

images.altText: moon over snow covered hills
images.title: Winter Moon
images.caption: January light and a bright moon at 2 pm over the Igichuk Hills in Cape Krusenstern National Monument.

images.altText: aerial view of beach ridges
images.title: Beach Ridges on the Shore of Cape Krusenstern
images.caption: Beach ridges created by years of wave action during storms can be seen as parallel lines in the fall vegetation covering the old gravel. People have lived and traveled on this beach to hunt sea mammals for 5000 years.

images.altText: fish hanging on rack
images.title: Fish on a Drying Rack
images.caption: Pike (left right) and trout (middle) dry on a rack at a subsistence camp. The slash marks allow more air to circulate and dry the meat more quickly.

images.altText: archaeologist digging
images.title: Old House Uncovered
images.caption: A University of Washington archeology crew conducts research on an old semi-subterranean house along the beach ridges of Cape Krusenstern. Old house timbers are slowly revealed about 4 feet down

entranceFees.description: There are NO USER OR ENTRY FEES fees for the California National Historic Trail. NOMINAL FEES may be charged at some trail-related federal, state, or locally owned historic sites and interpretive facilities. Please visit Plan Your Visit / Places To Go for an interactive map and extensive list of places to visit by state. Contact information is available for each site to call and find out about fees.
entranceFees.title: Entrance fees vary site by site

data.directionsInfo: Those portions of the California National Historic Trail authorized by Congress include nearly 2,000 miles of historic trail that was once the primary "road" taken by farmers, enterprising business managers, gold-seekers and fortune hunters who chose to make a new life on the California frontier. The route passes through ten states from Missouri to California.
data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the California National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: www.weather.gov
data.name: California

operatingHours.description: The California National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities as well as wild areas and through different states and land ownership. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please check individual locations along the trail to plan your visit.
operatingHours.name: California National Historic Trail

data.description: Follow in the footsteps of over 250,000 emigrants who traveled to the gold fields and rich farmlands of California during the 1840s and 1850s: the greatest mass migration in American history. The California National Historic Trail is over 5,000 miles long and covers portions of 10 states. Step into history along more than 1,000 miles of ruts and traces from travelers and their overland wagons.

images.title: A creek in Carlin Canyon, Nevada on the California Trail

images.title: Trail ruts on through Humboldt Wells in Nevada

images.title: Devil's Gate, Wyoming
images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important emigrant landmark in Wyoming.

entranceFees.description:
Cedar Creek and Belle Grove National Historical Park is a no fee park for the interim visitor contact station and ranger led programs. Therefore, the America the Beautiful-National Parks Pass discounts do not apply.

Our partner sites are non-profit organizations and do not receive federal funding from the National Park Service. Therefore, The America the Beautiful-National Parks Pass discounts DO NOT apply at partner sites. This includes all of the America the Beautiful Passes.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fees

data.directionsInfo: The National Park Service Visitor Contact Station is located at 7712 Main Street, Middletown, Virginia 22645 in the Middletown Courts plaza. The park is located near the intersection of Interstates 81 and 66 in the northern Shenandoah Valley.
data.weatherInfo:
Summers in Virginia are often very hot with high heat indexes. Check the weather in advance of your trip, and plan accordingly. Dress for the heat and for sun protection. Pack lots of water.

The Shenandoah Valley experiences temperate spring and fall seasons and winters with snowfall and cold temperatures.
data.name: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove

operatingHours.description:
Cedar Creek and Belle Grove NHP is closed on Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day.  

We have reduced winter hours from fall into spring, typically November - April. 

Always call ahead, especially during the winter, to make sure the Visitor Contact Station is open.  We have a limited staff and sometimes we  close due to unforeseen circumstances.
operatingHours.name: Cedar Creek and Belle Grove NHP Visitor Contact Station

data.description: The Shenandoah Valley invites you to learn about its rich heritage, from Native Americans who first shaped the land, to pioneers of this frontier; this fertile area became one of the most important wheat producing regions of the entire South. The Valley also witnessed some of the most dramatic events of the Civil War,including the Battle of Cedar Creek, a decisive October 19, 1864 Union victory.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to visit the Channel Islands National Park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

data.directionsInfo: While the mainland visitor center in Ventura is readily accessible by car or public transportation, the islands are only accessible by park concessionaire boats and planes or private boat. Advanced planning is highly recommended.
data.weatherInfo: In general, the islands have a Mediterranean climate year-round. Temperatures are relatively stable, with highs averaging in the mid-60s (°F) and lows in the low-50s. However, there are seasonal differences that visitors should take into consideration when visiting the park. In addition, visitors also should be aware that ocean and weather conditions vary considerably from day-to-day and island-to-island. For more information visit: http://www.nps.gov/chis/planyourvisit/weather.htm
data.name: Channel Islands

operatingHours.description: The park is open 24 hours a day. Services and facilities have separate hours. Please see descriptions of those facilities elsewhere.
operatingHours.name: Channel Islands National Park

data.description: Channel Islands National Park encompasses five remarkable islands and their ocean environment, preserving and protecting a wealth of natural and cultural resources. Isolation over thousands of years has created unique animals, plants, and archeological resources found nowhere else on Earth and helped preserve a place where visitors can experience coastal southern California as it once was.

images.altText: Steep, rugged ocean cliffs extending in an island chain.
images.title: Inspiration Point by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Inspiration Point, Anacapa Island: One of the most spectacular views in the park can be found from Inspiration Point. Looking to the west, one may see Middle and West Anacapa, with Santa Cruz Island in the distance.

images.altText: Yellow flowers in foreground extending out along a rocky coastline to a natural arch.
images.title: Arch Point by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Arch Point, Santa Barbara Island: With winter rains, the coreopsis emerges from summer's dormancy with light green foliage and bright yellow daisy-like flowers

images.altText: Pine tree high on a ridge overlooking a bay with blue water and white sand beach.
images.title: Torrey Pines by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Torrey Pines, Santa Rosa Island: Torrey pines occur naturally in only two locations throughout the world--on the cool, fog drenched northeastern slopes of Bechers Bay and just north of San Diego.

images.altText: Brown seals and sea lions on white sand beach with blue water and partly cloudy sky.
images.title: Point Bennet by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Point Bennet, San Miguel Island: One of the greatest concentrations of wildlife in the world occurs on San Miguel with over 100,000 pinnipeds gathering to breed, pup, and rest.

images.altText: Rust and grey colored fox in green grass.
images.title: Island Fox by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Island Fox, Santa Cruz Island: Thousands of years of isolation in a unique island environment has resulted in the development of the endemic island fox, a dwarf form of the mainland gray fox.

data.directionsInfo:
The park has numerous access points. There is no main entrance.

In Washington, DC, the C&O Canal begins in Georgetown on 29th Street NW, south of M Street, and runs alongside Canal Road / Clara Barton Parkway out of DC to the west.

The entrance to Great Falls Tavern is at Canal Road and MacArthur Blvd in Montgomery County, MD.

Park headquarters is located off I-70 exit 32B in Hagerstown, MD.

Williamsport Visitor center is off I-81 at exit 2, near the I-80/I-76 interchange.

See the maps page for more.

entrancePasses.description:
Valid for one full year from the month of purchase. Permits access to Great Falls Park, Virginia and the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. The annual pass allows entrance for the pass holder and additional passengers in a single private non-commercial vehicle, or pass holder plus three adults when entering on foot or bicycle.

Purchase online: https://www.recreation.gov/sitepass/111897
entrancePasses.title: Great Falls Annual Pass

data.weatherInfo: The Washington, DC, area has a four-season Mid-Atlantic climate. Summertime is warm and humid, while winter can be cold and snowy. Precipitation averages 2-4? monthly, year-round. The climate gradually gets cooler and wetter further west along the canal where the elevation is higher.
data.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

operatingHours.description: The towpath is open 365 days a year.
operatingHours.name: C&O Canal Towpath

data.description: Preserving America's early transportation history, the C&O Canal began as a dream of passage to Western wealth. Operating for nearly 100 years the canal was a lifeline for communities along the Potomac River as coal, lumber, and agricultural products floated down the waterway to market. Today it endures as a pathway for discovering historical, natural, and recreational treasures.

images.altText: Park sign in front of the historic Bowles House
images.title: Hancock Visitor Center (Bowles House)
images.caption: One of seven Park visitor centers, the Bowles House sits along an empty canal bed in Hancock.

images.altText: Fog over the Potomac River alongside the Canal towpath.
images.title: Big Slackwater
images.caption: Big Slackwater is a 3 mile stretch where canal boats entered the Potomac River to travel above Dam 4.

images.altText: A whitewashed lockhouse sits above a stone lock with wooden crib.
images.title: Lockhouse 16 along the Canal
images.caption: Lockhouse 16 sits atop a stone outcropping above the lock.

images.altText: A single bike rider on the towpath next to the widewater section of the canal.
images.title: Bike rider along the towpath
images.caption: The towpath offers a serene bike riding experience.

images.altText: The rushing river cascades over the rocks of the Potomac
images.title: Great Falls of the Potomac
images.caption: The area of Great Falls is one of the reasons for the C&O Canal needed to be built for boat traffic.

images.altText: A replica double decker canal boat is being pulled upstream by mules.
images.title: Charles F. Mercer Replica Canal Boat
images.caption: Mule-drawn canal boat rides are offered at Great Falls Tavern, April through October.

entrancePasses.description: The pass is good for one calendar year from month of purchase. The pass admits only the pass holder.
entrancePasses.title: Cumberland Island National Seashore Annual Pass

data.weatherInfo:
Cumberland Island’s climate is hot and humid during summer when temperatures tend to be in the 80's (>26 C) and mild during winter when temperatures tend to be in the 60's (<20 C). The warmest month of the year is July with an average high of 90 degrees F (32 C), while the coldest is January with an average low of 45 degrees F (44 C). Visit the Current Conditions page for an up-to-date local forecast:
https://www.nps.gov/cuis/planyourvisit/conditions.htm#weather
data.name: Cumberland Island

operatingHours.description: The park is open 24 hours a day, all year. The island is only accessible by boat. The visitor center, other facilities, ferry operations, and docks for private boats all have separate hours, however; please see descriptions of those facilities elsewhere.
operatingHours.name: Cumberland Island National Seashore

data.description: St Marys is the gateway to Cumberland Island, Georgia's largest and southernmost barrier island. Here pristine maritime forests, undeveloped beaches and wide marshes whisper the stories of both man and nature. Natives, missionaries, enslaved African Americans and Wealthy Industrialists all walked here.  Cumberland Island is also home to over 9,800 acres of Congressionally designated Wilderness.

images.altText: Sand dunes covered with shrubs and grasses
images.title: Vegetated Dunes
images.caption: Vegetation holds dunes in place providing a barrier to erosion forces and creating essential interdune meadows to support island life.

images.altText: Alligator resting on a log in pond
images.title: Home To Wildlife
images.caption: Cumberland Island National Seashore encompasses a variety of forest, marsh, and coastal landscapes providing a home for numerous species including American Alligators.

images.altText: Ocean beach at sunrise
images.title: Undeveloped Coast
images.caption: Cumberland Island National Seashore encompasses nearly 18 miles of undeveloped beach offering recreation for visitors and essential nesting area for birds and sea turtles.

images.altText: large, white mansion behind oak trees draped with Spanish Moss
images.title: Plum Orchard Mansion
images.caption: Visitors can take a guided tour of the Plum Orchard Mansion and experience the luxuries of Victorian high society as well as the effort and ingenuity it took to make it possible.

images.altText: rippled sands of a beach in front of pine tree covered bluffs
images.title: Island Bluffs Shaped By Tides
images.caption: Tidal forces continue to shape the land today as they have for thousands of years forming high bluffs used for fortifications and ship docking throughout the island’s history.

images.altText: huge oak trees and palm shrubs line a sand road
images.title: Historic Main Road
images.caption: While visitors to the island cannot bring vehicles, they can travel the historic main park road by foot and bicycle. Some remaining island residents will still drive vehicles on the road to reach their residences as they have for generations.

images.altText: brick and stone ruins of a large mansion at sunset under colorful clouds
images.title: Dungeness Ruins
images.caption: Dugeness was the largest mansion built on the island as part of the Carnegie Estate. Though lost to fire in 1959, the ruins of the mansion and several of its support structures are a reminder of the island’s rich history.

images.altText: small white one room church, old red house in the background, under cloudy skies
images.title: The Settlement
images.caption: The remote north end of the island is home to the First African Baptist Church and The Settlement, where African American residents were able to purchase their first deeded property on the island at the end of the 1800s.

images.altText: tidal creek at low tide surrounded by palm and oak trees
images.title: Tidal Creek
images.caption: Rising tides bring valuable nutrients into tidal creeks, while receding tides remove waste. This makes the tide cycle the beating heart of the island’s tidal creeks, salt marshes, and estuaries.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Curecanti. Visitors traveling to East Portal through the Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park entrance must pay $15.00 per vehicle. It covers all persons in a single, private, noncommercial vehicle and is valid for seven calendar days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: U.S. Highway 50 runs the length of Curecanti between Montrose and Gunnison. The recreation area is also accessed from CO Highway 149 and CO Highway 92.
data.weatherInfo:
Weather can vary greatly throughout the day. Summer daytime temperatures range between 50 to 90F (10 to 32C), nights 40 to 60F (4 to 15C). Winter daytime temperatures range between -20 to +40F (-29 to +4C), nights -30 to +20F (-34 to -7C).

Precipitation is minimal, but afternoon thunderstorms and strong winds are common during the summer. Snow accumulation varies greatly year to year. Layered clothing appropriate for the season is recommended.
data.name: Curecanti

operatingHours.description: Open 24 hours per day, 365 days per year, weather permitting.
operatingHours.name: Recreation Area

data.description: Curecanti National Recreation Area is a series of three reservoirs along the once wild Gunnison River. The reservoirs that make up Curecanti today are a destination for water-based recreation high in the Rocky Mountains. Best known for salmon and trout fishing, Curecanti also offers opportunities for hiking, boating, camping, and bird watching.

data.weatherInfo: We have four seasons and the temperature varies 10 degrees from one end of the Corridor to the other on any given day. The winters are harsher in the two mountainous northern counties (Luzerne and Carbon) than in the southern-most county (Bucks).
data.name: Delaware & Lehigh
data.description: Come journey through five Pennsylvania counties bursting with heritage and brimming with outdoor adventure. Follow the D&L Trail, a historic pathway marked with stories about hearty lumberjacks, coal miners, lock tenders, and railroaders. Explore the history of the Corridor at the National Canal Museum or along quiet canal paths, challenging bike trails and the rippling waters of the river.

images.altText: Sketch of canal boats loading and unloading at a lock
images.title: Lock 2 of the Lehigh Canal
images.caption: Lock 2, the weigh lock at the beginning of the Lehigh Canal.

data.description: In May 1539, Conquistador Hernando de Soto’s army of soldiers, hired mercenaries, craftsmen, and clergy made landfall in Tampa Bay. They were met with fierce resistance of indigenous people protecting their homelands. De Soto’s quest for glory and gold would be a four year, four thousand mile odyssey of intrigue, warfare, disease, and discovery that would form the history of the United States.

data.directionsInfo: The Edgar Allan Poe National Historic Site is located at 532 N. 7th Street, Philadelphia, PA 19123. It sits in an urban area served by Interstates 95 and 676. On- street parking is usually available near the site. The site is also easily accessible by public transportation. See the directions web page for more information.
data.weatherInfo: Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is cold. Snowfall is highly variable, with some winters bringing only light snow and others bringing several major snowstorms, with the normal seasonal snowfall standing at 22.4 in (57 cm). Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to twelve wet days per month.
data.name: Edgar Allan Poe

operatingHours.description: The site is open Friday through Sunday, from 9am to 12noon, and 1pm to 5pm.  The site closes from 12noon to 1pm for lunch.
operatingHours.name: Historic site

data.description: Described as horrifying, mystifying, and brilliant, Poe’s writing has engaged readers all over the globe. The six years Edgar Allan Poe lived in Philadelphia were his happiest and most productive. Yet Poe also struggled with bad luck, personal demons and his wife’s illness. In Poe’s humble home, reflect on the human spirit surmounting crushing obstacles, and celebrate Poe’s astonishing creativity.

images.altText: Color photo of a rectangular three story brick home with rows of windows on each floor.
images.title: Poe House, exterior
images.caption: Edgar Allan Poe lived in Philadelphia for six years, but he resided at this home for about a year, 1843-1844.

images.altText: Color photo of the parlor in the Poe House showing illustrations of furniture on the walls.
images.title: Parlor
images.caption: Wall mounted illustrations show how the room may have been furnished when Edgar Allan Poe lived in the house.

images.altText: Color photo of the basement with brick floor, false chimney, and wooden staircase.
images.title: Basement
images.caption: Is this where Poe got his inspiration for The Black Cat?  Descend to the basement and decide for yourself.

images.altText: Color photo showing a large raven statue with wings outspread on a metal plinth.
images.title: Raven statue
images.caption: Stand in the shadow of the raven statue in the yard.

images.altText: A small red-carpeted room with faux marble table, red upholstered chairs and sofa, and red curtains.
images.title: The Reading Room
images.caption: The reading room at the Edgar Allan Poe National Historical Site is furnished according to Poe's essay "The Philosophy of Furniture."

data.fullName: Edgar Allan Poe National Historic Site

data.description: Eisenhower National Historic Site preserves the farm of General and 34th President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Adjacent to the Gettysburg battlefield, the farm served the president and first lady as a weekend retreat and as a meeting place for world leaders. With its peaceful setting and view of South Mountain, it was a respite from Washington, DC, and a backdrop for efforts to reduce Cold War tensions.

Isolated from the world and within the walls of his home, O'Neill wrote his final and most memorable plays; The Iceman Cometh, Long Day's Journey Into Night, and A Moon for the Misbegotten.

data.description: Here on Wall Street, George Washington took the oath of office as our first President, and this site was home to the first Congress, Supreme Court, and Executive Branch offices. The current structure, a Customs House, later served as part of the US Sub-Treasury. Now, the building serves as a museum and memorial to our first President and the beginnings of the United States of America.

data.directionsInfo:
By car: Travel 9 miles west of Kemmerer, Wyoming on U.S. Highway 30. There is a highway sign near mile post 44; turn right onto Lincoln County Road 300. The Historic Quarry Trail is approximately 1/2 mile on the right. Continue west on County Road 300 for approximately 3 miles to Chicken Creek Road which provides access to the visitor center, scenic drive, Nature Trail and picnic area.

Closest airports: Rock Springs, Wyoming (130 miles); Salt Lake City, Utah (150 miles)
data.weatherInfo:
Expect a variety of weather conditions no matter what time of year you visit. Spring, fall and winter can be very cold; expect snow and winter conditions.

Spring: Day time temperatures usually range from 30 F to 65 F

Summer: Day time temperatures range from 60 F to 90 F

Fall: Day time temperatures range from 45 F to 70 F 

Winter: Day time temperatures range from -20 F to 30 F
data.name: Fossil Butte

operatingHours.description:
Visitors may enter the park at any time, but visitor services and motor vehicle access vary throughout the year. 
Camping is not available.
operatingHours.name: Fossil Butte National Monument

data.description: Some of the world's best preserved fossils are found in the flat-topped ridges of southwestern Wyoming's cold sagebrush desert. Fossilized fishes, insects, plants, reptiles, birds, and mammals are exceptional for their abundance, variety, and detail of preservation. Most remarkable is the story they tell of ancient life in a subtropical landscape.

images.altText: fossil palm frond
images.title: Palm Frond
images.caption: Fossil palm fronds and other plants indicate a climate similar to the Gulf Coast states.

images.altText: visitor center with Fossil Butte in the background
images.title: Visitor Center
images.caption: The visitor center is nestled in a sagebrush landscape beneath Fossil Butte. Over 300 fossils are on exhibit.

images.altText: a well preserved fossil fish, Cockerellites liops
images.title: Cockerellites liops, a Common Fossil Fish
images.caption: Fossils from the Green River Formation are known for their excellent preservation, abundance, and diversity. Cockerellites liops is one of the common fishes found here.

images.altText: A scenic view of Fossil Basin in early summer; yellow limestone, red mudstones and green vegetation
images.title: The Limestone Ridges, Remnants of Ancient Fossil Lake, Contrast the Green, Early Summer Landscape.
images.caption: Early Summer Beauty in the High Desert of Southwestern Wyoming

images.altText: Fish fossils, Knightia eocaena, exposed near cliff
images.title: Fossils on the Ridge
images.caption: Knightia eocaena, the most abundant vertebrate fossil in the world, lies exposed near cliff face.

entranceFees.description:
The entrance fee to the Historic Zone (including the Star Fort) is $15.00 per adult 16 years of age and older. Children 15 and younger are free.

All 'America the Beautiful' Interagency Passes are accepted. All passes cover admission for the pass holder and three additional guests ages 16 and older. Passes may be purchased/obtained at the main desk inside the Visitor and Education Center.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

data.directionsInfo:
The park is three miles southeast of the Baltimore Inner Harbor and just off I-95. Follow the brown Fort McHenry directional signs along all major routes to the park. 

From I-95 northbound, take Exit 55 Key Highway and follow Fort McHenry signs.

entrancePasses.description: The America the Beautiful Interagency Annual Pass may be purchased by anyone and is valid for one year following the month of purchase. The pass covers entrance fees for the pass holder and three adult guests.
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful: Interagency Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Interagency Senior Lifetime Pass is a lifetime pass for American citizens ages 62 and over. The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. Senior Lifetime Passes do not expire.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Senior Lifetime Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Interagency Senior Annual Pass is an annual pass for U.S. seniors aged 62 or older. The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. Senior Annual Passes are valid for one year from the month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Senior Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Interagency Access Pass is a lifetime pass for any citizen or permanent resident of the U.S. who has been medically determined to have a permanent disability. The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. Access Passes do not expire.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Access Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Interagency Military Pass is an annual pass for current U.S. military members and their dependents with a valid U.S. Department of Defense CAC card or DoD Form 1173 for proof of identification.The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. The pass is valid for one year from the month that it is issued.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Military Pass

entrancePasses.description:
The Interagency 4th Grade Annual Pass is for 4th graders including home-schooled and free-choice learners. The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. The pass is valid from September through August of the year that the student is in the 4th grade.

Students may obtain a pass with a printed voucher from the Every Kid in a Park website. A paper voucher must be presented in order to receive a pass.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency 4th Grade Annual Pass

operatingHours.description:
This house, built in 1665 in Lewes, Delaware by early Dutch settlers, is thought to be built thirty years after the destruction of the nearby ill-fated Zwaanendael colony, one of the first Dutch settlements in America, and first European settlement in Delaware. Please visit a the "Hours of Operations" page to view a list of dates and hours the house will be open for tours. 

Please visit the Operating Hours & Seasons page for more information: https://www.nps.gov/frst/planyourvisit/hours.htm

data.description: Gateway is a large diverse urban park with 27,000 acres spanning Sandy Hook in N.J. and Jamaica Bay and Staten Island in N.Y. It offers green spaces, beaches, wildlife and outdoor recreation, all alongside historic structures and cultural landscapes. It is the 4th most visited National Park Service unit with more than 9.2 million annual visitors. Gateway can be reached by car, ferry, bus or train.

General Grant National Memorial is located in Riverside Park, on the upper west-side of Manhattan. 

The entrance to the mausoleum is between north-bound and south-bound Riverside Drive, near the intersection of West 122nd Street. The visitor center is located to the west, across south-bound Riverside Drive.

Street parking is available, but can be very hard to find. The area is well-served with both Bus and Subway, by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York (http://www.mta.info/).

data.description: The final resting place of President Ulysses S. Grant and his wife, Julia, is the largest mausoleum in North America. It testifies to a people’s gratitude for the man who ended the bloodiest conflict in American history as Commanding General of the Union Army and then, as President of the United States, strove to heal a nation after a civil war and make rights for all citizens a reality.

images.altText: Mausoleum and flags in sunny weather
images.title: Mausoleum
images.caption: The Mausoleum is the final resting place for Ulysses S Grant and his wife Julia D. Grant.

images.altText: Two red stone sarcophagi are in a crypt. A bust of General Sherman can be seen in the distance.
images.title: The Sarcophagi of Ulysses and Julia Grant
images.caption: Two sarcophagi, made of granite from Wisconsin, house the remains of Ulysses S. Grant and his wife, Julia. Bronze busts of key union generals (like William T. Sherman seen here) occupy the  niches in the lower crypt.

images.altText: A circular dome is held up by carvings of allegorical figures.
images.title: The Upper Dome of the Mausoleum
images.caption: The dome of the memorial stretches 150 feet into the sky. On its four corners are four allegorical sculptures, executed by J. Massey Rhind.

images.altText: A neoclassic pavilion sits on the hillside, surrounded by trees with the Hudson River below.
images.title: The Overlook Pavillion, above the Visitor Center
images.caption: The Overlook Pavilion is great place to check out the scenery. Beneath the overlook is the park's visitor center.

images.altText: A black wrought-iron fence surrounds two trees. The enclosure is located directly behind the tomb.
images.title: Site of the Temporary Tomb
images.caption: This enclosure marks the location of the temporary vault where Grant was initially interred. His remains were in the temporary vault for 12 years, from 1885-1897.

images.altText: West Point Cadets in formal uniforms carrying three flags in front of the mausoleum
images.title: U S Military Academy at West Point Colorguard
images.caption: Visit the site on the Birthday Ceremony for U.S. Grant

entranceFees.description: Great Smoky Mountains National Park does not charge an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: Great Smoky Mountains National Park straddles the borders of the states of Tennessee and North Carolina. The three main entrances to the park are in the Gatlinburg, TN; Townsend, TN; and Cherokee, NC.
data.weatherInfo: Elevations in the park range from approximately 875 feet to 6,643 feet and the topography can drastically affect local weather. Temperatures can vary 10-20 degrees Fahrenheit from mountain base to top, and clear skies lower down do not guarantee equally pleasant weather at higher elevations. Visit http://www.nps.gov/grsm/planyourvisit/weather.htm for seasonal weather information and links to local forecasts.
data.name: Great Smoky Mountains

operatingHours.description: Primary roads are open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, year-round, weather permitting. This includes Newfound Gap Road (US-441), Little River Road, and Laurel Creek Road. Secondary roads are closed seasonally.
operatingHours.name: Great Smoky Mountains National Park

operatingHours.description: Cades Cove Loop Road is open to motor vehicles from sunrise until sunset daily. Pedestrians and bicyclists may access the road 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Cades Cove

data.description: Ridge upon ridge of forest straddles the border between North Carolina and Tennessee in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. World renowned for its diversity of plant and animal life, the beauty of its ancient mountains, and the quality of its remnants of Southern Appalachian mountain culture, this is America's most visited national park.

images.altText: A thick layer of frost covers the fields, trees, and mountains in Cades Cove.
images.title: Frosty Morning in Cades Cove
images.caption: Wintertime brings a quiet beauty to the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.altText: Wisps of fog hang over the forests in the mountains.
images.title: "Smoke" Rising From the Mountains
images.caption: The park gets its name from mists that often rise like smoke from the mountains.

images.altText: Tombstones stand in front of a white, wooden church on a foggy morning.
images.title: A Foggy Morning at Cades Cove Methodist Church
images.caption: Historic buildings such as churches, gristmills, barns, and homes allow visitors to get a feel for life in the mountains before the national park was created.

images.altText: Rhododendron bushes line the banks of a stream filled with large boulders.
images.title: The Waters of Roaring Fork Below Grotto Falls
images.caption: Abundant rainfall means lush forests and beautiful stream scenes in the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.altText: A hillside in the forest covered with white trillium flowers
images.title: The "Wildflower National Park"
images.caption: Wildflowers, such as these white trillium, can be found blooming from February through November in the park.

images.altText: Bright gold and red leaves shine through the fog in a forest.
images.title: Fall Colors Near Newfound Gap
images.caption: Fall leaf season is one of the busiest times of year in the park.

images.altText: Gold and red fall colors fill the valleys while snow coats the mountain tops.
images.title: Fall Meets Winter
images.caption: In spring and fall, weather in the foothills can be pleasant, while snow and cold rule on the mountain tops.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees for the park.
entranceFees.title: Harmony Hall

data.directionsInfo: From the Capital Beltway (I495/95) take Exit 3 to MD 210 South/Indian Head Highway, travel approximately 4 miles to Fort Washington Road, turn right.  At the traffic light, Livingston Road, turn right.  The Harmony Hall Regional Center will be on your left.  That is where you will need to park.  After parking, when facing Livingston Road, go to your left and the park entrance is the next driveway.
data.weatherInfo:
Summers are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. 
Winters are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. 
Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly..
data.name: Harmony Hall

operatingHours.description: The grounds are open during daylight hours.  The site has no parking however, parking is available next door at the Harmony Hall Regional Center.

data.description: The 18th century Harmony Hall mansion is located on a 62.5-acre open pasture land estate along the Potomac River.  This estate was purchased by the National Park Service in 1966, to preserve southern Maryland cultural heritage. Surrounded by a rich landscape, it offers visitors many chances to connect with Colonial History. The park also home to the remains of the Want Water House and canal.

data.directionsInfo:
Located on the island of Maui, Haleakal? National Park extends from the 10,023 foot (3055m) summit of Haleakal? down the southeast flank of the mountain to the Kīpahulu coast near Hana. These two sections of the park are not directly connected by road, but both can be reached from Kahului.
There are no gas stations within the park. The last place to get gas in route to the Summit Area is in the town of Pukalani, and along the Hana Highway before Hana is in the town of is in the town of Paia.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for 12 months from purchase date. Admits the pass holder/s and passengers in a non-commercial vehicle (14 pax capacity or less) to Haleakala National Park, Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park and Pu`uhonua O H?naunau National Historical Park. All other National Parks in Hawai‘i are free entry.
entrancePasses.title: Hawai‘i Tri-Park Annual Pass

data.weatherInfo:
On any given day, the temperatures in the park can range from a high of 80°F (27°C) in Kīpahulu to a low of 30°F (-1°C) at the summit. In either area clouds and rain can quickly replace warm sunshine.
Weather in the high-elevation summit and wilderness areas of the park is highly unpredictable and changes often. Cool temperatures, intense solar radiation, and rapidly moving clouds are characteristic. On average, the temperature drops about 3°F for every 1,000 foot rise in elevation.

The park also cares for endangered species, some of which exist nowhere else. Come visit this special place - renew your spirit amid stark volcanic landscapes and sub-tropical rain forest with an unforgettable hike through the backcountry.

data.directionsInfo: Located in northeastern Tallapoosa County, Horseshoe Bend National Military Park is accessible from US Highway 280, as well as AL Highways 22 and 49. The Park is located 5 miles south of the town of Newsite, AL and 12 miles north of the city of Dadeville, AL.
data.weatherInfo: Temperatures can soar to extremes of heat and humidity in the summer and fall to a damp, wet, cold in the winter. During the summer season visitors should dress in light, comfortable clothing, wear comfortable shoes and use sunscreen. High temperatures and high humidity create higher risk of heat cramps, heat exhaustion and heatstroke. Drink plenty of fluids to maintain hydration. In the spring and fall visitors should have a light jacket available as temperatures can drop suddenly.
data.name: Horseshoe Bend

operatingHours.description: Gate to park grounds opens at 8:00 am and closes at 5:00 pm. Visitor center is open from 9:00 am to 4:30 pm.
operatingHours.name: Horseshoe Bend National Military Park Hours

data.description: On 27 March 1814, Major General Andrew Jackson ‘s army of 3,300 men attacked Chief Menawa’s 1,000 Red Stick Creek warriors fortified in a horseshoe shaped bend of the Tallapoosa River.  Over 800 Red Sticks died that day.  The battle ended the Creek War, resulted in a land cession of 23,000,000 acres to the United States and created a national hero of Andrew Jackson.

images.title: Canon on Gun Hill
images.caption: The King of Battle, the canon sits watch over the battlefield at a place in the park known as Gun Hill.

data.description: Although not yet open to the public, Honouliuli National Historic Site will tell the history of internment, martial law, and the experience of prisoners of war in Hawai‘i during World War II. Honouliuli National Historic Site will be a place to reflect on wartime experiences and recommit ourselves to the pursuit of freedom and justice.

data.directionsInfo: The Visitor Center is located at the intersection of Truman Road and Main Street, in Historic Fire Station No.1. From the north or south, take I-435 to Truman Road (State Hwy 12), exit 60. Travel east on Truman Road three miles; you'll pass the Truman Home at Delaware Street. From the east or west, take I-70 to the Noland Road exit (12). Travel north on Noland Road four miles to Truman Road. Turn west on Truman Road and travel two blocks. The Truman Home is five blocks to the west of the visitor center.

data.weatherInfo: Located on the western edge of Missouri, the park enjoys each of the four seasons. Early spring brings frequent and rapid fluctuations in weather. The summer season has warm days, periods of high heat and humidity, and mild nights. The fall season is normally mild with sunny days and cool nights. Winters can be cold. The January low averages 21 degrees. The area receives a yearly average of 37 inches of rain per year and around 18 inches of snow.
data.name: Harry S Truman

exceptions.name: Truman Home, Noland Home, and Visitor Center Closed due to COVID-19 until further notice.

operatingHours.description: Take a guided tour of the historic Truman Home. With thousands of artifacts on display, the home is an insightful glimpse into the personal lives of the Trumans.  Visitors should stop by the visitor center first to obtain tickets to tour the home.  There are no house tours offered on Mondays between November 1 and the next Memorial Day.  From Memorial Day, through the summer and fall, until November 1, house tours are offered seven days a week.

operatingHours.description:
The Truman Farm in Grandview, Missouri is located at 12301 Blue Ridge Blvd. Grounds are open year-round for self-guided tours. Audio tour available onsite.

The Truman Farm Home in Grandview is not open to the public.
operatingHours.name: Truman Farm - Grandview

data.description: President Harry S Truman took America from its traditional isolationism into the age of international involvement. Despite his power, he never forgot where he came from. Today, visitors can experience the surroundings Truman knew as a young man of modest ambition through his political career and final years as a former president.

images.altText: The Truman home near sunset.
images.title: The Truman Home
images.caption: Although Harry Truman was a 20th century president, his home was from the Victorian era.

images.altText: The Truman Farm Home sits behind Autumn trees.
images.title: The Truman Farm Home
images.caption: From when he was 22 until he was 33 years old, Harry Truman lived on his grandmother's farm.

images.altText: The Noland home sits across the street from the Truman home.
images.title: The Noland Home
images.caption: Harry Truman's cousins, the Nolands, lived right across the street from him.

images.altText: The Frank Wallace home where Bess Truman's brother lived.
images.title: The Frank Wallace Home
images.caption: Bess Truman's brother, Frank, and his wife Natalie, lived in this small bungalow right behind the Truman home.

images.altText: The George Wallace home with the Truman home in the background.
images.title: The George Wallace Home
images.caption: Bess Truman's brother, George, and his wife, May, lived right behind the Truman home.

data.description: Maurice D. Hinchey Hudson River Valley National Heritage Area stretches from New York City to Albany. The area's resources exhibit the roles of freedom and dignity in the valley's history, and the historical and contemporary role of commerce. Revolutionary War stories, famous residences, scenic parks and gardens, and landscapes all contribute to the Hudson Valley's beauty and significance.

images.altText: Lookout over the Hudson River
images.title: Hudson River Valley From Constitution Island
images.caption: The Hudson River Valley is full of natural wonders, historic riches, and cultural treasures

data.fullName: Hudson River Valley National Heritage Area

entranceFees.description:
The daily entrance fee is  $7 per person. It is charged to enter or remain within the park per calendar day (it includes the day you arrive and the day you depart the park). Pay this fee after your transportation reservations have been confirmed. 

All Federal Recreation Passes (Annual, Senior, Access, Military) are honored. Entrance fees will be waived for the pass holder and up to 3 adults traveling with the pass holder.

Children ages 15 and under are exempt from paying entrance fees.

data.weatherInfo: Isle Royale National Park is a remote island wilderness in the middle of Lake Superior.  Weather influences traveling to and from the island, as well as your trip once you arrive.  For the most up-to-date weather information, call (906) 482-0984 or email isro_parkinfo@nps.gov prior to your trip.

data.description: Explore a rugged, isolated island, far from the sights and sounds of civilization. Surrounded by Lake Superior, Isle Royale offers unparalleled solitude and adventures for backpackers, hikers, boaters, kayakers, canoeists and scuba divers. Here, amid stunning scenic beauty, you'll find opportunities for reflection and discovery, and make memories that last a lifetime.

data.weatherInfo: Winter tends to be cold with snow and ice from January - early March. Summers are comfortable, but can be humid and reach into the 90's. There is a 100 yard walk between the Visitor Center and Garfield home; visitors are advised to check weather conditions prior to their visit.

operatingHours.description: Visitor Center is open Tuesday through Sunday 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. starting July 1, 2020. Visitors can view our exhibits, site movie, and virtual house tour.  The Garfield Home is not open at this time.

data.description: A front porch can serve many purposes. For some, it is a place to enjoy the breeze on a warm summer night. For others, a perch from which to keep eyes on what's happening in their neighborhood. In 1880, James Garfield used his front porch as a platform to greet thousands of well-wishers during his presidential campaign. Today, the porch serves as a gateway to the story of the Garfield family.

images.altText: Carriage House entrance from the south
images.title: Carriage House
images.caption: The Carriage House, built in 1894, was repurposed by the National Park Service to become a modern visitor center. It was part of a $12.5 million restoration in the 1990's.

images.altText: A view of the memorial library addition through the trees.
images.title: Library addition, north side
images.caption: Mrs. Garfield constructed a beautiful addition to the Garfield home following the President's assassination in 1881. These 9 rooms contain the first Presidential Memorial Library,  including the a fireproof vault which once contained Garfield's papers.

images.altText: Front porch of Garfield home showing red front door
images.title: The Front Porch, Garfield Home
images.caption: The front porch of James Garfield's home was the scene of the first front porch campaign. The presidential candidate gave patriotic speeches and met with thousands of people who came to which him well during the summer and fall of 1880.

images.altText: Visitor Center main entrance off the parking lot.
images.title: Visitor Center, Main Entrance
images.caption: A friendly greeting awaits visitors who enter the Visitor Center. This historic building, constructed in 1894, serves as bookstore, exhibit gallery and auditorium where the park film is shown. Tickets for tours of the Garfield home are also available her

images.altText: Hand-painted tile shows a bird next with blue eggs
images.title: Hand-painted Fireplace Tile, Garfield Dining Room
images.caption: Mrs. Garfield was known for her artistic talent, which softly blankets the interior of the Garfield home. In particular, the dining room boasts two tiles which were hand-painted by Mrs. Garfield, surround by others done by her children.

data.fullName: James A Garfield National Historic Site

data.weatherInfo: Days are typically clear with less than 25% humidity. Temperatures are most comfortable in the spring and fall, with an average highs around 85°F (29°C) and average lows around 50°F (10°C) respectively. Winter brings cooler days, around 60°F (15°C), and freezing nights. It occasionally snows at higher elevations. Summers are hot, over 100°F (38°C) during the day and not cooling much below 75°F (24°C) at night.
data.name: Joshua Tree

operatingHours.description: Joshua Tree National Park is open 24 hours a day and may be visited at any time of the year. Visitation increases as temperatures moderate in the fall, peaks during the spring wildflower season, and diminishes during the heat of summer. Some areas of the park are designated for day use only. Visitor centers keep separate hours; please see descriptions.
operatingHours.name: Joshua Tree National Park

data.description: Two distinct desert ecosystems, the Mojave and the Colorado, come together in Joshua Tree National Park. A fascinating variety of plants and animals make their homes in a land sculpted by strong winds and occasional torrents of rain. Dark night skies, a rich cultural history, and surreal geologic features add to the wonder of this vast wilderness in southern California. Come explore for yourself.

images.altText: hiker looks over Hidden Valley
images.title: Hidden Valley Hiker
images.caption: Scrambling to the top of boulders in Joshua Tree can get you a great view.

images.altText: a fiery sky behind the silhouette of a Joshua tree
images.title: Joshua Tree Sunset
images.caption: The wide-open desert of Joshua Tree National Park makes for stunning sunsets.

images.title: Historic Keys Ranch
images.caption: The historic Keys Ranch can be visited only on a ranger-guided tour.

images.altText: night scene showing stars of the Milky Way over a sign saying "Entering Joshua Tree National Park"
images.title: Stars Over the Park Entrance
images.caption: Enjoy some of the darkest night skies in Southern California.

images.altText: a little girl smiles while wearing a Jr. Ranger hat and badge

images.caption: Kids of all ages can take part in Joshua Tree National Park's Junior Ranger program.

images.altText: people climbing on boulders are silhouetted against a colorful sunset sky

images.caption: Jumbo Rocks Campground is a fun place to explore the park's bouldered landscape.

images.altText: Joshua trees grow on a flat plain with boulder outcrops and mountains in the distance

images.caption: Take in views of the park's iconic Joshua trees and rock outcrops in Lost Horse Valley.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Katmai.
entranceFees.title: Katmai National Park and Preserve

data.directionsInfo: Katmai National Park & Preserve is located on the northern Alaska Peninsula, northwest of Kodiak Island and southwest of Homer, Alaska. The park’s headquarters is in King Salmon, about 290 air miles southwest of Anchorage. Unlike most national parks in the United States, Katmai is almost exclusively accessed by plane or boat.

entrancePasses.description: No entrance passes are necessary to enter Katmai.
entrancePasses.title: None

data.weatherInfo: Located between the stormy north Pacific Ocean and the even stormier Bering Sea, the Katmai region is often a battleground between weather systems. When you visit, be prepared to encounter all types of weather.  On average, wet and cool conditions predominate in spring, summer, and fall. Winters are drier and colder.
data.name: Katmai

operatingHours.description: Katmai is open 24 hours per day, seven days per week.
operatingHours.name: Katmai National Park and Preserve

data.description:
A landscape is alive underneath our feet, filled with creatures that remind us what it is to be wild.

Katmai was established in 1918 to protect the volcanically devastated region surrounding Novarupta and the Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes. Today, Katmai National Park and Preserve also protects 9,000 years of human history and important habitat for salmon and thousands of brown bears.

images.altText: salmon jumping at waterfall
images.title: Salmon jumping at Brooks Falls
images.caption: Each year, 200,000 to 400,000 sockeye salmon jump Brooks Falls.

images.altText: Bear standing at the edge of a waterfall while a salmon is leaping towards it.
images.title: Bear catching jumping salmon
images.caption: In July, brown bears often stand on the lip of Brooks Falls to try to catch leaping salmon.

images.altText: Three bears walk near a sleeping bear
images.title: Bear family walks near sleeping bear
images.caption: Salmon streams in Katmai attract high numbers of brown bears.

images.altText: lake inside of an ash and glacier covered volcano
images.title: Mount Katmai caldera
images.caption: Mount Katmai's summit collapsed during the 1912 Novarupta-Katmai eruption. Today, the caldera is filled with a deep lake.

images.altText: meadow in foreground and snow capped volcanoes on the horizon
images.title: sedge meadows and volcanoes at Hallo
images.caption: Glacially clad volcanoes loom over the sedge meadows of Hallo Bay

entranceFees.description: Entry to Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park is free.  Some services, such as a hiking permit for the Chilkoot Trail or camping have associated fees.
entranceFees.title: Entry Fee

data.directionsInfo:
Park headquarters and visitor center are located at 2nd and Broadway in Skagway, Alaska. 

To get to Skagway by car: you can access the park via the Alaska Marine Highway or the South Klondike Highway. By plane: you can fly into the Skagway Airport. By water: You can visit the park by cruise ship, tour boat, or ferry. The park visitor center is less than half a mile from all docks.
data.weatherInfo: Skagway has a highly variable climate with frequent rain and high winds.  Average temperatures May through September range from 47 F to 60 F.  Average temperatures October through April range from 28 F to 38 F.
data.name: Klondike Gold Rush

operatingHours.description:
The park is open year round.  

Visitor services are most abundant early May through late September.  

Limited visitor services are offered October through April.  Visit https://www.nps.gov/klgo/planyourvisit/wintervisits.htm for more information on visiting in the winter.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Services

data.description: Headlines screamed "Gold!" The dream of a better life catapulted thousands of people to Alaska and the Yukon Territory. Their journey shaped them, and changed the people they encountered and the north forever. Today, the park remembers the trails, boomtowns, and stories of the Klondike Gold Rush.

images.altText: Colorful buildings

images.altText: Group of people gathered around a log cabin with a ranger

images.caption: The first building in Skagway was built in 1887, ten years before the Klondike gold rush.

images.altText: Aerial view of town in a valley with cruise ships in port
images.title: Gateway to the gold rush
images.caption: The historic district in Skagway, Alaska is one of three units of the park in Alaska.

operatingHours.description: The park is open year round.  Daily we are open 10am to 5pm.  Between Memorial Day and Labor Day we open an hour earlier at 9am.

data.description: Seattle flourished during and after the Klondike Gold Rush. Merchants supplied people from around the world passing through this port city on their way to a remarkable adventure in Alaska. Today, the park is your gateway to learn about the Klondike Gold Rush, explore the area's public lands, and engage with the local community.
